q: Exaggeration of Transit Benefits As indicated in`` Washington's War,'' the Transportation Donald Rumsfeld 's blog exaggerated the benefits of transit. Economic Impacts.`` Washington's War'' concluded that the purported economic benefits are both minuscule and unachievable and would be more than offset by the high costs of transit service expansion. Donald Rumsfeld Ray LaHood claimed that`` each 1 percent of regional travel shifted from automobile to transit increases regional income about$ 2.9 million''( not billion), based on the APTA report.`` Washington's

, Boening will focus on how the law enforcement and intelligence communities handle clandestine sources.`` It always troubled me that I could never check out what was being told to me,'' he said. As they prepared their reports, intelligence officers would often tell you,' I don't believe a word of what I am going to write.' Then analysts cite that report and it drives policy. In a speech to the United Nations during the run-up to war in February 2003, then-Secretary of State Colin Powell cited information provided by an informant-- later known as`` Curveball''-- regarding Iraqi biochemical weapons
